Statistical Reasoning through Computation and R Brandon LeBeau and Andrew S. Zieffler 2019-08-16 Preface This book provides a modern statistical reasoning and introduction to statistics text. Computation, using the R programming language, are used instead of relying on traditional statistical theory.

Chapter 2 Visualization library(ggformula) library(mosaic) library(RColorBrewer) head(CPS85) ## wage educ race sex hispanic south married exper union age sector ## 1 9.0 10 W M NH NS Married 27 Not 43 const ## 2 5.5 12 W M NH NS Married 20 Not 38 sales ## 3 3.8 12 W F NH NS Single 4 Not 22 sales ## 4 10.5 12 W F NH NS Married 29 Not 47 clerical ## 5 15.0 12 W M NH NS Married 40 Union 58 const ## 6 9.0 16 W F NH NS Married 27 Not 49 clerical 2.1 Explore Distributions 2.1.1 Histograms gf_histogram(~ wage, data = CPS85) 2.1.1.1 Adjust Number of Bins gf_histogram(~ wage, data = CPS85, bins = 15) 2.1.1.2 Adjust Binwidth gf_histogram(~ wage, data = CPS85, binwidth = 1) 2.1.1.3 See Bin location gf_histogram(~ wage, data = CPS85, binwidth = 1, color = 'black') 2.1.1.4 Plot Customization gf_histogram(~ wage, data = CPS85, binwidth = 1) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) gf_histogram(~ wage, data = CPS85, binwidth = 1) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Wage ($ per hour)", y = "Number") 2.1.2 Density Plots gf_density(~ wage, data = CPS85) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Wage ($ per hour)", y = "Density") 2.2 Conditional (Multivariate) Distributions 2.2.1 Distribution Plots by Groups gf_histogram(~ wage, data = CPS85, binwidth = 1, fill = ~ sex) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Wage ($ per hour)", y = "Number") gf_density(~ wage, data = CPS85, fill = ~ sex) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Wage ($ per hour)", y = "Density") 2.2.2 Violin Plots gf_violin(wage ~ sex, data = CPS85) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Sex", y = "Wage ($ per hour)") gf_violin(wage ~ sex, data = CPS85, fill = 'gray85') %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Sex", y = "Wage ($ per hour)") 2.2.3 Ridge Plots? 2.3 Scatterplots 2.3.1 2d Scatterplots gf_point(wage ~ age, data = CPS85) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Age (in years)", y = "Wage ($ per hour)") 2.3.2 Add Color and Shapes gf_point(wage ~ age, data = CPS85, color = ~ sex) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Age (in years)", y = "Wage ($ per hour)") gf_point(wage ~ age, data = CPS85, shape = ~ married) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Age (in years)", y = "Wage ($ per hour)") gf_point(wage ~ age, data = CPS85, color = ~ sex, shape = ~ married) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Age (in years)", y = "Wage ($ per hour)") 2.3.3 Faceting gf_point(wage ~ age, data = CPS85, color = ~ sex) %>% gf_facet_wrap(~ married) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Age (in years)", y = "Wage ($ per hour)") 2.4 Hex Bins gf_hex(wage ~ age, data = CPS85) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Age (in years)", y = "Wage ($ per hour)") 2.4.1 Adjust color gf_hex(wage ~ age, data = CPS85) %>% gf_refine(scale_fill_gradientn(colors = rev(brewer.pal(9, "YlGnBu")), values = c(0, exp(seq(-5, 0, length.out = 100))))) %>% gf_theme(theme_bw()) %>% gf_labs(x = "Age (in years)", y = "Wage ($ per hour)") 2.4.2 Label Interesting Points May need some new data for this. 2.5 Additional Resources
